qas.question: What happens to the working fluid in a closed loop system?
What sort of system releases the exhaust steam into the atmosphere?
What working fluid is used in a mercury vapor turbine?
What is the typical working fluid in a steam engine?
What happens to the working fluid in a chemistry system?
What sort of system releases the exhaust steam into the boiler?
What working fluid is used in a mercury cycle?
What is the typical working fluid in a vapor turbine?
What can the working fluid in a boiler cycle operate as?

context: The working fluid in a Rankine cycle can operate as a <b8_0>closed loop system<b8_0/>, where the working fluid is <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b4_0>recycled continuously<b4_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, or may be an "<a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b5_0>open loop<b5_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>" system, where the exhaust steam is directly released to the atmosphere, and a separate source of <b7_0>water<b7_0/> feeding the boiler is supplied. Normally <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>water<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> is the fluid of choice due to its favourable properties, such as non-toxic and unreactive chemistry, abundance, low cost, and its thermodynamic properties. <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b6_0>Mercury<b6_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> is the working fluid in the mercury vapor turbine. Low boiling hydrocarbons can be used in a binary cycle.
